Item.SEODescription: Learn about Office Add-ins that allow you to make your solution a native part of Office across Windows, Office Online, Mac and the IPad.
Learn about the software and device requirements for running Office Add-ins.
Apply best practices to build Office Add-ins that optimize the user experience.
Get started building an Office Add-in with Visual Studio
Get started building Office Add-ins with any editor, on a Mac or Windows PC.
Use the UX design pattern templates for Office Add-ins to create UI extensions.
Use add-in commands in your add-in to extend the default Office UI in Excel, Word, and PowerPoint.
Design icons for add-in commands that integrate seamlessly with the Office UI.
Provides guidelines for data visualizations in Office Add-ins.
Walks you through the basics for using Fabric JS.
Walks you through the basics for using Fabric React.
Plan the end-to-end process for developing task pane, content, and Outlook add-ins to extend Office applications.
Find out how to opt in to get the latest builds of Office.
Make your Office Add-ins available in Office for iPad.

Item.text: Tips for creating add-ins with Angular 2
Item.SEODescription: Use Angular 2 to develop Office Add-ins.
Use the Office Add-in JavaScript template in Visual Studio to create an add-in that uses TypeScript.
Use the Dialog API to open dialog boxes in your Office Add-in.
Use the OAuth 2.0 authorization framework in your Office Add-ins.

Item.text: Create an SSO add-in using ASP.NET
Create an SSO add-in using Node.js

Item.SEODescription: Use the VersionOverrides element in your add-in manifest to define add-in commands.
Find out how to specify Office hosts and API requirements in your manifest.

Item.text: Requesting permissions for API use in content and task pane add-ins
Item.SEODescription: Specify the level of API access your add-in requires in your manifest.
Update the JavaScript files (Office.js and app-specific .js files) and the add-in manifest validation file used in your Office Add-in project to version 1.1.
Understand the functional areas of the JavaScript API for Office, which is implemented in the Office.js file.

Item.text: Support for content and task pane add-ins
Item.SEODescription: Describes the different permission levels that you can declare in your content or task pane add-in's manifest to specify the level of JavaScript API access your add-in requires for its features.
Reference the JavaScript API for Office library (Office.js and associated application-specific .js files) from its content delivery network (CDN) location.
An add-in must ensure that both the DOM and the Office Add-ins runtime environment are loaded before running its own custom logic.
Develop Office Add-ins using the nested callbacks and promises patterns asynchronous programming patterns supported by the JavaScript API for Office.
Understand the options for persisting add-in state and settings data for content, task pane, and Outlook add-ins.
Office Add-ins are secured by a runtime framework, a multiple-tier permissions model, and the ability to govern use of memory, CPU, and network resources.

Provides a brief overview of ways to address the same-origin policy limitations that prevent a script loaded from one domain from getting or manipulating properties of a document from another domain in an Office Add-in.
Provide locale-specific content for an Office Add-in, including UI strings, add-in name, description, icon, source file, and date/time format.
Apply resource usage limits to your Office Add-ins and optimize the performance of your add-in.
Install an Office Add-in running on Windows for testing.

Item.text: Sideload Office Add-ins in Office Online for testing
Item.SEODescription: See how to load an add-in into an Office application for testing.
Install an Outlook add-in for testing.
Sideload your Office Add-in onto an iPad or Mac to test how it will run in Office for iOS or Office for Mac.

Item.text: Attach a debugger from the task pane

Item.SEODescription: Use the Debugger from the F12 developer tools on Windows 10 to debug Office add-ins.
Use Office Online to debug add-ins without running Office on the Windows platform - for example, if you're developing on a Mac.
Debug Office Add-ins running on an iPad or Mac by using the Weinre remote web inspector.
Troubleshoot issues your users are having with Office Add-ins.

Item.SEODescription: Troubleshoot issues with your Office Add-ins manifest.

Item.text: Host an Office Add-in on Microsoft Azure
Item.SEODescription: Use Visual Studio 2015 and the Microsoft Office Developer Tools to publish to and then host an Office Add-in on Microsoft Azure.

Item.text: Create better add-ins for Word with Office Open XML
Item.SEODescription: Use Office Open XML to insert rich content via Word add-ins. Edit the Office Open XML to simplify the markup and minimize the payload.
